segment.source: 4776(S, F) The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.
segment.target: 4776(S, F) The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4776(S, F) The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.
segment.target: Describes security event 4776(S, F) The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.

segment.source: 4776(S, F): The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.
segment.target: 4776(S, F): The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time that a credential validation occurs using NTLM authentication.
segment.target: This event generates every time that a credential validation occurs using NTLM authentication.

segment.source: This event occurs only on the computer that is authoritative for the provided credentials.
segment.target: This event occurs only on the computer that is authoritative for the provided credentials.

segment.source: For domain accounts, the domain controller is authoritative.
segment.target: For domain accounts, the domain controller is authoritative.

segment.source: For local accounts, the local computer is authoritative.
segment.target: For local accounts, the local computer is authoritative.

segment.source: It shows successful and unsuccessful credential validation attempts.
segment.target: It shows successful and unsuccessful credential validation attempts.

segment.source: It shows only the computer name (Source Workstation) from which the authentication attempt was performed (authentication source).
segment.target: It shows only the computer name (Source Workstation) from which the authentication attempt was performed (authentication source).

segment.source: For example, if you authenticate from CLIENT-1 to SERVER-1 using a domain account you will see CLIENT-1 in the Source Workstation field.
segment.target: For example, if you authenticate from CLIENT-1 to SERVER-1 using a domain account you will see CLIENT-1 in the Source Workstation field.

segment.source: Information about the destination computer (SERVER-1) is not presented in this event.
segment.target: Information about the destination computer (SERVER-1) is not presented in this event.

segment.source: If a credential validation attempt fails, you will see a Failure event with Error Code parameter value not equal to “0x0”.
segment.target: If a credential validation attempt fails, you will see a Failure event with Error Code parameter value not equal to “0x0”.

segment.source: The main advantage of this event is that on domain controllers you can see all authentication attempts for domain accounts when NTLM authentication was used.
segment.target: The main advantage of this event is that on domain controllers you can see all authentication attempts for domain accounts when NTLM authentication was used.

segment.source: For monitoring local account logon attempts, it is better to use event “4624: An account was successfully logged on” because it contains more details and is more informative.
segment.target: For monitoring local account logon attempts, it is better to use event “4624: An account was successfully logged on” because it contains more details and is more informative.

segment.source: This event also generates when a workstation unlock event occurs.
segment.target: This event also generates when a workstation unlock event occurs.

segment.source: This event does not generate when a domain account logs on locally to a domain controller.
segment.target: This event does not generate when a domain account logs on locally to a domain controller.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: no specific requirements.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: no specific requirements.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Authentication Package Type = UnicodeString: the name of Authentication Package which was used for credential validation.
segment.target: Authentication Package Type = UnicodeString: the name of Authentication Package which was used for credential validation.

segment.source: It is always “MICROSOFTAUTHENTICATIONPACKAGEV10” for 4776 event.
segment.target: It is always “MICROSOFTAUTHENTICATIONPACKAGEV10” for 4776 event.

segment.source:
Note
Authentication package is a DLL that encapsulates the authentication logic used to determine whether to permit a user to log on.
segment.target:
Note
Authentication package is a DLL that encapsulates the authentication logic used to determine whether to permit a user to log on.

segment.source: Local Security Authority (LSA) authenticates a user logon by sending the request to an authentication package.
segment.target: Local Security Authority (LSA) authenticates a user logon by sending the request to an authentication package.

segment.source: The authentication package then examines the logon information and either authenticates or rejects the user logon attempt.
segment.target: The authentication package then examines the logon information and either authenticates or rejects the user logon attempt.

segment.source: Logon Account Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that had its credentials validated by the Authentication Package.
segment.target: Logon Account Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that had its credentials validated by the Authentication Package.

segment.source: Can be user name, computer account name or well-known security principal account name.
segment.target: Can be user name, computer account name or well-known security principal account name.

segment.source: Examples:
segment.target: Examples:

segment.source: User example: dadmin
segment.target: User example: dadmin

segment.source: Computer account example: WIN81$
segment.target: Computer account example: WIN81$

segment.source: Local System account example: Local
segment.target: Local System account example: Local

segment.source: Local Service account example: Local Service
segment.target: Local Service account example: Local Service

segment.source: Source Workstation Type = UnicodeString: the name of the computer from which the logon attempt originated.
segment.target: Source Workstation Type = UnicodeString: the name of the computer from which the logon attempt originated.

segment.source: Error Code Type = HexInt32: contains error code for Failure events.
segment.target: Error Code Type = HexInt32: contains error code for Failure events.

segment.source: For Success events this parameter has “0x0” value.
segment.target: For Success events this parameter has “0x0” value.

segment.source: The table below contains most common error codes for this event:
segment.target: The table below contains most common error codes for this event:

segment.source: Error Code
segment.target: Error Code

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: The username you typed does not exist.
segment.target: The username you typed does not exist.

segment.source: Bad username.
segment.target: Bad username.

segment.source: Account logon with misspelled or bad password.
segment.target: Account logon with misspelled or bad password.

segment.source: - Generic logon failure.
segment.target: - Generic logon failure.

segment.source: Some of the potential causes for this:
segment.target: Some of the potential causes for this:

segment.source: An invalid username and/or password was used
segment.target: An invalid username and/or password was used

segment.source: LAN Manager Authentication Level mismatch between the source and target computers.
segment.target: LAN Manager Authentication Level mismatch between the source and target computers.

segment.source: Account logon outside authorized hours.
segment.target: Account logon outside authorized hours.

segment.source: Account logon from unauthorized workstation.
segment.target: Account logon from unauthorized workstation.

segment.source: Account logon with expired password.
segment.target: Account logon with expired password.

segment.source: Account logon to account disabled by administrator.
segment.target: Account logon to account disabled by administrator.

segment.source: Account logon with expired account.
segment.target: Account logon with expired account.

segment.source: Account logon with "Change Password at Next Logon" flagged.
segment.target: Account logon with "Change Password at Next Logon" flagged.

segment.source: Account logon with account locked.
segment.target: Account logon with account locked.

segment.source: The local account store does not contain secret material for the specified account.
segment.target: The local account store does not contain secret material for the specified account.

segment.source: No errors.
segment.target: No errors.

segment.source: Table 1.
segment.target: Table 1.

segment.source: Winlogon Error Codes.
segment.target: Winlogon Error Codes.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4776(S, F): The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.
segment.target: For 4776(S, F): The computer attempted to validate the credentials for an account.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “Logon Account” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “Logon Account” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Logon Account” value (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Logon Account” value (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: To monitor activity of specific user accounts outside of working hours, monitor the appropriate Logon Account + Source Workstation pairs.
segment.target: To monitor activity of specific user accounts outside of working hours, monitor the appropriate Logon Account + Source Workstation pairs.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “Logon Account” that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “Logon Account” that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Logon Account” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Logon Account” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers: You might have certain computers from which certain people (accounts) should not log on.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers: You might have certain computers from which certain people (accounts) should not log on.

segment.source: Monitor the target Source Workstation for credential validation requests from the “Logon Account” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Source Workstation for credential validation requests from the “Logon Account” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “Logon Account” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “Logon Account” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: If NTLM authentication should not be used for a specific account, monitor for that account.
segment.target: If NTLM authentication should not be used for a specific account, monitor for that account.

segment.source: Don’t forget that local logon will always use NTLM authentication if an account logs on to a device where its user account is stored.
segment.target: Don’t forget that local logon will always use NTLM authentication if an account logs on to a device where its user account is stored.

segment.source: You can use this event to collect all NTLM authentication attempts in the domain, if needed.
segment.target: You can use this event to collect all NTLM authentication attempts in the domain, if needed.

segment.source: Don’t forget that local logon will always use NTLM authentication if the account logs on to a device where its user account is stored.
segment.target: Don’t forget that local logon will always use NTLM authentication if the account logs on to a device where its user account is stored.

segment.source: If a local account should be used only locally (for example, network logon or terminal services logon is not allowed), you need to monitor for all events where Source Workstation and Computer (where the event was generated and where the credentials are stored) have different values.
segment.target: If a local account should be used only locally (for example, network logon or terminal services logon is not allowed), you need to monitor for all events where Source Workstation and Computer (where the event was generated and where the credentials are stored) have different values.

segment.source: Consider tracking the following errors for the reasons listed:
segment.target: Consider tracking the following errors for the reasons listed:

segment.source: Error to track
segment.target: Error to track

segment.source: What the error might indicate
segment.target: What the error might indicate

segment.source: User logon with misspelled or bad user account
segment.target: User logon with misspelled or bad user account

segment.source: For example, N events in the last N minutes can be an indicator of an account enumeration attack, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: For example, N events in the last N minutes can be an indicator of an account enumeration attack, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon with misspelled or bad password
segment.target: User logon with misspelled or bad password

segment.source: For example, N events in the last N minutes can be an indicator of a brute-force password attack, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: For example, N events in the last N minutes can be an indicator of a brute-force password attack, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon outside authorized hours
segment.target: User logon outside authorized hours

segment.source: Can indicate a compromised account; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: Can indicate a compromised account; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon from unauthorized workstation
segment.target: User logon from unauthorized workstation

segment.source: Can indicate a compromised account; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: Can indicate a compromised account; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon to account disabled by administrator
segment.target: User logon to account disabled by administrator

segment.source: For example, N events in last N minutes can be an indicator of an account compromise attempt, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: For example, N events in last N minutes can be an indicator of an account compromise attempt, especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon with expired account
segment.target: User logon with expired account

segment.source: Can indicate an account compromise attempt; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: Can indicate an account compromise attempt; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: User logon with account locked
segment.target: User logon with account locked

segment.source: Can indicate a brute-force password attack; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: Can indicate a brute-force password attack; especially relevant for highly critical accounts.
